abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely. Several lessons
            are drawn from the project, in particular, that the
            sustainability of village infrastructure facilities require
            not only, the secured beneficiaries' commitment to
            contribute to capital costs, but to finance operational, and
            maintenance costs as well. This is reflected in the
            successful privatization of two village facilities, which
            initially rented these facilities, to later transfer
            ownership to the benefiting cooperatives/societies, allowing
            time to evaluate their own technical, financial, and
            administrative capacity, prior to a full ownership transfer.
            Nonetheless, the expansion of fish production, which require
            a committed improvement in resource management, is
            endangered by the potential of over-exploitation of fish
            resources. This factor, if not addressed through better
            regulatory, and management capabilities, may lead to self
            defeat. The flexibility, and support from donor cooperation
            was crucial in, not only guaranteeing the project survival,
            and eventually its success, but also in responding to
            changes in project environment, and needs, allowing quick
            moves from project resources, to more appropriate purposes.
            However, the reduced autonomy of the Project Unit through
            the Ministry of Fish Wealth, hindered decision-making, thus
            delaying completion, and full disbursement.

18152639.admreg: Middle East and North Africa,Middle East and North Africa
18152639.theme: Rural non-farm income generation,Gender,Trade facilitation and market access

repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Yemen - Fourth Fisheries
            Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objectives of the project are
            to:  (a) expand fish catches and improve processing; (b)
            improve the efficiency of the domestic and export marketing
            of fish; (c) improve the assessment and management of fish
            resources; and (d) help improve the position of women in
            fishing communities.. The project will provide for:  (a)
            construction of primary facilities for fish handling in
            seven villages and of a road between two fishing villages to
            improve access; (b) import of: intermediate technology
            vessels, construction material for fishing boats, outboard
            engines and fishing gear, and a fleet of insulated and
            refrigerated trucks and plastic boxes for fish marketing;
            (c) technical assistance for the Coastal Fisheries
            Corporation, the National Corporation for Fish Marketing,
            cooperatives and the Ministry of Fisheries; (d)
            strengthening of the Marine Science and Resources Research
            Institute's fish stock assessment and resource
            management program and environmental research capability;
            and (e) services for women in fishing communities.
